greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: The number of ways of putting n labeled items into k labeled boxes so that each box receives at least 2 objects.
comment: Equivalently, the number of ordered set partitions of the set [n] into k blocks of size at least two. When the boxes are unlabeled or the set partitions unordered we obtain A008299.

The number of doubly-surjective functions f:[n]->[k], where a doubly-surjective function f has pre-image sets of size at least 2 for each element of the codomain. Also, the number of ways to distribute n different toys to k different children so that each child gets at least two toys. - _Dennis P. Walsh_, Apr 09 2013
T(n,k) is the number of chains 0 = x_0 < x_1 < ... < x_k = 1 in the Boolean lattice of rank n, such that x_i is not covered by x_(i+1) for all i. - _Geoffrey Critzer_, Jul 15 2018
link: Muniru A Asiru, Table of n, a(n) for n = 2..626
Dennis Walsh, Notes on doubly-surjective finite functions
formula: Recurrence relation: T(n+1,k) = k*(T(n,k) + n*T(n-1,k-1)). T(n,k) = k!*A008299(n,k).
T(n,k+j) = Sum_{i=0..n} C(n,i)*T(i,k)*T(n-i,j). - _Dennis P. Walsh_, Apr 09 2013
T(n,k) = Sum_{j=0..k} (-1)^j*C(k,j)*(Sum_{i=0..j} C(j,i)*C(n,i)*i!*(k-j)^(n-i)) for 1 <= k <= n/2 and n >= 2. - _Dennis P. Walsh_, Apr 10 2013
example: T(4,2) = 6: The arrangements of 4 objects into 2 boxes { } and [ ] so that each box contains at least 2 items are {1,2}[3,4], {1,3}[2,4], {2,3}[1,4] and the 3 other possibilities where the contents of a pair of boxes are swapped.
mathematica: t[n_, k_] := k! * Sum[ (-1)^i*Binomial[n, i] * Sum[ (-1)^j*(k - i - j)^(n - i) / (j!*(k - i - j)!), {j, 0, k - i}], {i, 0, k}]; Table[ t[n, k], {n, 2, 14}, {k, 1, n/2}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Apr 10 2013 *)
results.author: _Peter Bala_, Dec 04 2011
